* * * - been omitted, for fear the animal's attraction might render the Manager liable 1o the penalties of the 2nd & 3rd of Victoria, cap, 47., sec. i.vt., by which it is enacted, that no person
within the Districts of the Metropolitan Police, shall " use any dog for the purpose, of drawing or helping

Theatre Koyaf* Hay-Market^
Mr. B. WEBSTER, Sole Lessee and Manager, Old Bromplon.
$St This Theatre has lately, at considerable eIpence, been perfectly

WARSEED and VEIVTILATED.

Under the superintendence of J O H N SYLVESTER, Esq. C. E., on the most improved principles,
whereby a constant supply of pure air, at an agreeable temperature, is secured and an equal volume
of the vitiated atmosphere of the house is removed.

ties of the 2nd &3rd of Victoria, eap. 47., sec LVI., by which it is enacted, that no person
withi. the Districts of the Metropolitan Police, shall " ttse any dog for the purpose of drawing or helping
to draw," j-c. jv.. j-c.

OPINIONS of the PRESS
We say of Mr. Dion Bourcicault's Comedy of ' Old ,
Heads atid Young1 Hearts' produced l | j * night, that it is th*
roost amusing five-act production that his been seen for years, ]
and that it has pleased—honestly pleased, the public to a deree that may defy the exertions of any opposing theorist to
ispute its claim to popularity. His pifce is carefully written
throughout, and he has introduced points in his dialogue, which
are worthy of any author. The author has thrown himself
•with full zeal upon his writing, and has pushed along the dialogue with a buoyancy of spirit, liveliness, and brilliancy, which
completely carry an audience along in spite of themselves.
The curtain descended amid a perfect roar of applause. No
drama could have been more successful, and we must say the,^
success was fully deserved. The author has produced a work
that has more elements of popularity than any of equaj length
that we have seen for a long, long time. The actors played as
well as the Boost fidgetty dramatist could desire, and the decorative part has been most liberally managed by Mr. Webster,
who received a marked acknowledgment on his entrance.—
The Times, and Weekly Chronicle.
Here we have a comedy of teal English growth, and with
a right hearty old English title. We must now, in Justice,
record <h« no less palpable merit of the author—his dialogue
in which he, with an affluence almost reckless, dispenses
antithesis, repartee, metaphor, simile, and pathos, with a
farilitv and a brilliancy that uwakened many an echo of
bo sterous laughter and hearty applause ; nothing' interrupted
the continuous explosions of laughter and plaudits which
reuthed tkeir climax when Mr. Farren upon joining the hands
of the lovers, uttered the following valedictory lines, with a
touching tenderness and truth which found their response in
every breast:—" Bless your young faces.'' The comedy was
very equally acted.—.Horning Post.
Applause and luughtet were frequent during the evening,
and thecurtuin fell amid a hurricane of cheers. Every scene
contains some unexpected turn, ingeniously contrived. There
.is,,considerable advance for the better in. the t.tw <rf this
'co'medy*. Tne comedy is put splendidly upon the stage, and
nothing, in short, has been Spared in the way of scenic
©m!n'l!ishmenl.—Mornimj Herald.
It may run torn season or two, and even, we a !mit be very
opulnt There « much thai is striking and biillinnt in the
diialogue of this play. The scenery we must not omit to state,
wv.S most gorgeous. Seldom indeed have we seen anything
©n the stage more perfect than the laying out of the drawing
room of Lord Pompion.—Morning Chronicle, & Standard,
Mr. Webster has produced a good and successful comedy.
" Old Heads rind Young Hearts" has met with the most full
and decided success. •' Old Heads and Young Hearts" is a
pleasing and promising •'''*•, and fortunately it does not
promise more titan is performed. What we like about this
play is, that it does not partake of the heartless tone of the
mongrel, frivolous kind of drama which we have half-borrowed, half-wnitaled, from the French. There is a great
deal of good English " heart'' in it, which does not beat exclusively in theypung bosoms of the piece ; for the youngest
heart (tfiat i», ill. warmest) among them all is conjoined with
the oldest head, in the person of Mr. Rural, the country Clergyman—a sketch in which sweetness, pathos, in|h imour are
combined IP • manner worthy o( Goldsmith. Excellent dialogue, solid as well as brilliant, smart, playful, satirical, and
indicating knowledge of human nature. This play deserves
i's suoees.-i-JoAn BlU
Bourcioault's comedy i» drawing capital houses, and moreover it dtseryes to draw them. We saw it on thefiNttand on
the fourth nights, and it was astonishing to w ittiess the improvement that has been made in that short interval. Not only
were all t h . performers at home in their characters, but some
small pieces had been cut out wtifch were evident excrescences, and the dialogne ran with unusual spirit and closeness of
repartee. W e are sure that it will be a lasting favorite with
play-goers, and we rejoice to see them so numerous. Soma
have complained that the two last acts are not quite so good
as the three fin*; we dispute the position, but it is of course
necessary to give an author a little lime to unwind the intricacies of his plot, and the plot of the new comedy is here and
there considerably involved. W e do not scruple to say that it
is perhaps the best comedy of modern times,nnd we only wonder that it did not gain Webster's prise of £500.—Observer.
Mr. Bourcicault's new comedy, " Old Heads and Young
Hea«s," was decidedly and deservedly successful. It is a
legitimate comedy, full* of situation, equivoque, and fun, with
« very smart and lively dialogue, a little sentiment, and a good
deal of wit. It never flags for a moment, and When it is over
you say that it will quite bear being seen again.—Aye tk Aryut.

AVBER.

LE SERHENT,"

We would fain have a proof now and then that invention,
constructive power, wit, repartee, have not yet wholly deserted
the young writers of England ; and sometimes, though at long
intervals, we have evidence trrat these qualities are yet to be
found. They are all to, be found, for instance, in the Comedy
of ' Old Heads and Young Hearts," from the pen of Mr. D .
JBourcicault, produced last night at this Theatre, and as a consequence, it v as completely successful. The dialogue is free
and flowing, sprightly, and at no time dull. Only premising
farther that the applause was waim>and coidial during thefirst
act, that it was well and equally sustained throughout the other
three, and came to a close with enthusiasm ,at the end of the
fifth. The piece js admirably brought out; the scenery is excellent—those of the boudoir and the suite of drawing-rooms
are perfect in their way. Altogether its success must be gratifying both to the author and the management. The performers were called before the curtain to r< eeive the applause of the
audience for their efforts, and were thanked by the cheers of a
house croweed to excess.—Bun.
The acting of this Comedy deserves a particular notice.—
Dramatic and Musical Review.
A more perfect triumph could not be coveted by author or
manager, surrounded by a galaxy of talent ol which no other
boards can boast, to the achievement of a grand and permanent
success. Tog-ether with the public we cordially rejoice that
this successful play has fallen into the hands of Mr. Webster,
who deserved the best specimen of the legitimate drama, not
only for his industry in forcing b it for his supplying such a
hot-house of artistic talent to acclimatise the plants of British
genius. May our hearts ever be young enough, and our heads
*
never too old, to relish the fruit of good writing and good
acting conjoined in the new comedy at the Hayrnarket.—Era.
HAYMVRKET.—"Old Heads and Young He.-t8," (from
the pen of Bourcicault), which made its entree to public life
at the Haymnrket Theatre, on last Monday evening, with a
degree of rcldt that muvt tyive satisfied author, manager,
actbrs, and ev*ry person interested in its success. The sparkling fire of repartee; and variety of incident, never allowed the
attention of the (»udienee to be withdrawn for n moment. I t
commences w ell, and proceeds through the greater part of the
three first acts with remarkable ease and increasing interest;
at the commencement of the fourth net the author threw in a
fresh stock of embarrassments and mistakes, which the concluding scene of the fifth act triumphantly redeems, and the
curtain descends amidst a torrent of well deserved applause.
The characters of the comedy are all drawn with vigour, and
some cf them with great originality. We have but rarely
witnessed a scene oiji the stage so replete with natural pathos
as that in wbrth Tt5m discovers that I^dy Alice loves his
brother. The piece had full justice done to it by all the performers ; the mf»e en scene, too, was in choice taste. The suite
of drawing-rooms iti'Lurd Pompion's house, with the assemblecl company, wits a beautiful,-.nd perfect realisation of the
subject in all its parts. The applause at the fall of the curtain was most enthusiastic.—Sunday Times.
" Old Heads and Young He**.*'' was triumphantly successful, and wi nt with roais of applause from beginning to end.
The comedy will run as long, and prove ns great a favorite as
Mr. Bcurcicnult's first production, " London Assuiance,"—
Railway Bell
" Old Heads and Young Hearts" is the very best thing that
has appeared for years—an assertion possibly borne.ut by its
triumphant success. The w riling was sparkling and pungent;
the portrayal of character natural and unaffected; and in til.
scenes of society introduced, nothing was outraged by ignorance of the class from which the^y were drawn. The comedy
went with continued bursts of cheering, until the curtain fell
amidst a whirlwind of applause.—tilustrattd London News.
A more w arm and sincere impulse than that which, at the
fall of the curtail, on Monday night, actuated a crowded house
in successively calling forth the author, the manager, and the
performers, could not have been wished for by each and all.—
Great Gun.
The play opens wilh great spirit, and the whole of the first
act, amid all the difficulty of introducing the characters, is excellent. The seeond,third and fourth acts eusue,and are marked
throughout by a number of very smart sayings and pithy observations, which would do credit to the true class of comedy,
and were deservedly taken and much applauded.— Literary
Gaxette,
We congratulate Mr. Webster on his new piece of " Old
Heads and Young Hearts, and Mr. Bourcicault upon th*
triumph he has achieved; certain it is that it is very clever
and something more—it is very successful.—i}i»patch.

OPINIONS or the PRESS.
W e say of Mr. Dion Bourcicav.lt'- Comedy of * Old
Reads and Young Hearts' produced last night, that it is the
moat amusing five-act production that has been seen for years,
and that it has pleated—honestly pleased, the public to a de«ree that may defy the exertions of any opposing theorist to
dispute its claim to popularity. His piece is carefully written
throughout, and he has introduced points in his dialogue, which
are worthy of any author. The author has thrown himself
with full -eal upon his writing, and lias pushed along the dialogue with a buoyancy of spirit, liveliness, and brilliancy, which
completely carry an audience along in spite of themselves.
The curtain descended amid a perfect roar of applause. No
drama cotdd have been more successful, and we must say the
success was fully deserved. The author has produced a work
that has more elements of popwlarity than any of equal length
that we have seen for a long, long time. The actors ployed as
well as the most fidgetty dramatist could desire, and the decorative part has been most liberally managed by Mr. Webster,
who received a marked acknowledgment on his entrance.—
The Times, and Weekly Chronicle.
Here we have a Comedy of real English growth, and with
a right hearty old English title. W e must now, in justice,
record the no less palpable merit of the author—his dialog.*in which he, with an affluence almost reckless, dispenses
antithesis, repartee, metaphor, simile, and pathos, with a
facility and a brilliancy that awakened many an echo of
boisterous laughter and hearty applntt-e; nothing interrupted
the continuous explosions.of laughter and plaudits which
reached their climax when Mr. Farren upon joining the hands
of the lovers, uttered the following valedictory lines, with a
touching tenderness and truth wltieh found (heir response in
every breaat:—"Bless your young faces." &<•.
The comedy
was Very equally acted.—Morning Pott,
Applause and laughter were frequent during the evening,
.nd the'tttrtain fell amid a hurricane of cheers. Bv«y scene
eoDtains some unexpected turn, ingeniously contrived. There
is considerable advance for the better in the tone of this
comedy. The comedy is put splendidly upon the stage, and
nothing, in short, has been spared in the way of scenic
embellishment.—Morning Herald.
It m»y run (bra season or two, and even, we admit be very
popular". There is much that is striking and brilliant in the
dialogue of this piny. The scenery we must not oroil to state,
was most gorgeous. Seldom indeed have we seen anything
on the stage more perfect than the laying out of the drawing
room of Lord Pompion.—Morning Chtonic/r, ft Standard.
Mr Webster ha* produced a good and successful comedy.
*'Old Heads and Young Hearts has met with the most full
and decided success. •' Old Heads and Young Hearts" is a
pleasing and promising title, and fortunately it does not
promise more than is performed. What we like about this
play i», that it doe* not partake of the heartless tone of the
mongrel, frivolous kind of drama which we hove half-borrowed, half-imitated, from the French. There is a j^rcnt
deal of good English " heart" in it, which does not beat exclusively in the young bosom* of the piece ; for the youngest
heart (tfiatis, the wannest) among them all is conjoined with
the oldest head, in the person of Mr. Rural, the country Clergyman—a sketch in which sweetness, pallios, and humour are
combined in a manner worthy of Goldsmith. Excellent dialogue, solid SI well us brilliant, smart, playful, satirical, and
indicating knowledge of human nature. This play deserves
its succes.—John Hid/.
Bourcicault's comedy is drawing capital houses, and moreover it deserves to draw them. We saw it on the first and on
the fourth nights, and it was astonishing to witness the improvement that has been made in that short interval. Not only
were all the performers at home in their characters, but some
small pieces had been cutout which were evident excrescences, and the dialogne ran with unusual spirit and closeness of
Tepartee. We are sure that it will be a lasting favorite with
play-goera, and we rejoice to see them so numerous. Some
have complained that the two last nets arc not quae so good
as the three first; we dispute tbe position, but it is of course
necessary to give an author a little time to unwind the intricacies of his plot, and the plot of the new comedy is here and
there considerably involved. We do not scruple to say that it
is perhaps the beat comedy of modem times.and v^ e only wonder that it did not gain Webster's prize of £500.—Observer.
Mr. Bourcicault's new comedy, " Old Heads and Young
Hearts," was decidedly and deservedly successful. It is a
legitimate comedy, full of situation, equivoque, and fun, with
a very smart and lively dialogue, a little sentiment, and a good
deal of wit. it 'lever flags for a moment, and when it is over
you say that it will quite bear being seen again.—Age & Argus.
mmmmmmm i».«sii.iiiBSii»ii.iii.aii.-^^

,

.

„

,

.

We would fain have a proof now and then that invention,
constructive power, wit, repartee, have not yet wholly deserted
the young writers of England; and sometimes, though at long
intervalSjWe have evidence that these qualities are yet t o be
found. They are all to be found, for instance, in the Comedy
of'« Old Heads and Young Hearts," from the pen of Mr. D .
Bourcicault, produced last night at this Theatre, and as a consequence, it was completely successful. The dialogue is free
and flowing, sprightly, and at no time dull. Only premising
farther thai the applause was warm and coidial during the first
act, that it was well and equally sustained throughout the other
three, and came to a close with enthusiasm at the end of the
fifth. The piece is admirably brought out; the scenery is excellent—those of the boudoir and the suite of drawing-rooms
are perfect in their way. Altogether its success must be gratifj ing both to the author and the management. The performers were called before the curtain to receive the applause of the
audience for their efforts, and were thanked by the cheers of a
house crowded to excess.—Sun.
The acting of this Comedy deserve* a particular notice.—
Dramatic and Musical Review.
A more perfect triumph could not be coMited by author or
manager, surrounded by u galaxy of talent of which no other
hoards can boast, to the achievement of a grand and permanent
success Together with the public we cordially rejoice that
this successful play has fallen into the hands of Mr. Webster,
who deserved the best specimen of the legitimate drama, not
only for his industry in forcing, but for his supplying such a
hot-house of artistic talent to acclimatise the plants of British
jUeiiins. May our hearts ever be young enough, and our heads
never too old, to relish the fruit of good writing and good
acting conjoined in the new comedy at the Hay market.—Era.
HAVMARKET.—"Old Heads arid Young Hearts," (from
the pen of Boun icault), which made its entree to public life
at the Haymiirket Theatre, on ln«t Monday evening, with a
degree of eclat that must have satisfi--d author, manager,
actors, and e\ er, person interested in its success The sparkling fire of repartee, and variety of incident, never allowed the
attention of the audience to be withdrawn for a moment. It
commences w ell, and proceeds through the greater part of the
three first acts w ith remarkable ease and increasing interest;
at the commencement of the fourth act the author threw in a
fresh stock of embarrassments and mistakes, which the concluding scene of the fifth act triumphantly redeems, and the
curtain descends amidst a torrent of well deserved applause.
The characters of the comedy are all drawn with vigour, and
some of them with great originality. W e have but rarely
witnessed a scene on the stage so replete with natural pathos
«s that in which Tom discovers that I^acly Alice loves his
brother. The piece had full justice done to it by all the performers ; the mise en scene, too, was in choice taste. The suite
of drawing-rooms in Lord Pompicn'u house, with the assembled company, was a beautiful nnd perfect realisation of the
subject in all its parts, ffc. applause St tbe fall of the curtain was most enthusiastic--Sr/nctc??/ Tivtes.
" Old Heads mid Young Hearts" was triumphantly' successful, and went with roars of iqiplnuse from he£>inning to end.
The comedy will run as long, and prove as great a favorite as
Mr. Bourcicault's first production, ' London Assurance."—
Railway Bell.
" O l d Heads and Young Heart-."' is the very best thing that
has appeared for years—an assertion possibly borne©ut by it»
triumphant success. The writing was sparkling and pungent;
the portrayal of character natural and unaffected ; and in the
scenes of society introduced, nothing was outraged by ignorance of the class from which they were drawn. The comedy
went with continued bursts of cheering, until the curtain fell
amidst a whirlwind of applause.—Illustrated fimtftfi News.
A more warm and sincere impulse than that which, at the
fall of the curtain on Monday night, actuated a crowded house
in successively calling forth the thor, the manager, and the
performers, could not have been wished for by each and all.—
Great Gun.
The play opens with great spirit, and the whole of the first
act, amid all the difficulty of introducing the characters, is excellent. The second.third and fourth acts ensue,andare marked
throughout by a number of very smart savings nnd pithy observations, which would do credit to the true class of comedv
and were deservedly taken and much applauded. — Literary'
Gazette.
*
We congratulate Mr. Webster on his new piece of " Old
Heads and Young Hearts, and Mr. Bouicicault upon the
triumph he has achieved ; certain it is that it is very clever
and something more—it is very successful—Dispatch.

W e say of Mr. Dion Boureicault's Comedy of ' Old
Heads and Young Hearts' produced last night, that it is the constructive power, wit, repartee, have not yet wholly deserted
most amusing five-act production that has been seen for years, the young writers of England; and sometimes, though at long
and that it has pleased—honestly pleased, the public to a de- intervals, we have evidence that these qualities are yet to be
gree that may defy the exertions of any opposing theorist to found. They are all to be found, for instance, in the Comedj
dispute its cluim to popularity. His piece is carefully written of" Old Heads and Young Hearts," from the pen of Mr. D .
throughout, and he has introduced points in his dialogue, which Bourcicault, produced last night at this Theatre, and as a conarc worthy of any author. The author has thrown himself sequence, it was completely successful. The dialogue is fret
with full zeal upon his writing, and has pushed along the dia- and flowing, sprightly, and at no time dull. Only premising
logue with a buoyancy of spirit, liveliness, and brilliancy, which farther that the applause was warm and coidial during the first
act, that it was well and equally sustained throughout the other
completely carry an audience along in spite of themselves.

drama could hare been more successful, and we must say the fifth. The piece is admirably brought out; the scenery is e*>
success was fully deserved. The author has produced a work eellent—those of the boudoir and the suite of drawing-rooms
that has more elements of popularity than any of equal length are perfect in their way. Altogether its success must be gratithat we have seen for a long, long time. Mr. B o t m i e a u l t s n e w comedy, " Old H e a d s and Y o u n g
Hearts,"' was decidedly and deservedly successful. I t is s
legitimate comedy, full of situation, equivoque, and fun, with
a very smart a n d lively dialogue, a little sentiment, and a g o o d
deal of wit. I t never flags for a moment, and when it is oi er
you say t h a t it will quite bear heiug seen a g a i n . — A y e & Argus.

W e would fain have a proof now and then t h a t invention,
constructive power, wit, repartee, have n o t yet wholly deserted
t h e young writers of England ; and sometimes, though a t loag
intervals, we have evidence that these quauties are y«* t o b .
found. T h e y are all to be found, for instance, i n t h e C o m e d y
of •' Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s , " from the pen of M r . D .
Bourcicault, produced last n i g h t at this T h e a t r e , and as a c o o sequence, it was completely successful. T h e d k l o g u e k free
and flowing, sprightly, and at n o time dull. Only premising
farther t h a t t h e applause was worm and ooidial during the first
act, that it was well and equally sustained throughout the other
three, and came to a close with enthusiasm at (he e n d of t h s
fifth. T h e piece is admirably brought o u t ; t h e scenery k e x cellent—those of the boudoir and the suite of drawing-rooma
are perfect in their way. Altogether its success must b e gratifying both t o the author and t h e management. T h e performers Were called before the curtain to receive the applause of t h .
audience for their efforts, and were thanked by the cheers of a
house crowded to excess.—Svn.

M r Bourcicaull, whose freshness of spirit delighted t h e
town taken h e presented his London sissu>a%ce, p r o d u c e d a
new comedy here on Monday, under t h e title of Old Heath
and Young Heaiti,
a n d it met with decided success. W e
admit thnt much of the applause was elicited by t h e a c t i n g ,
and scenic arrangements j but the [day itself possesses t h e
el ement s of success : it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of

to t h e new comedy was hearty a n d universal.—liclTs New
lf>, kit/ Messenger.
Old H e a d s and Y o u n g Hcnrts w a s played for t h e second
time last night, a n d again received with rapturous a p p l a u s e
by a crowded a u d i e n c e . W e have much pleasure t o affirm

a u t h o r ' s reputation a s a dramatist. It evinces a most a c c u r a t e
k n o w l e d g e of stnei> effect. 'I he comedy is admirably b r o u g h t
out, nnd t h e performers everted themaelvei to t h e tit m e t .
The comedy, we arc certain, will have a long and prosperous
c a r e e r . — Theatrical
Obsnvrer.
T h e production of new a n d original pieces is so Inudable
to a mnnayerial attempt, thnt Mr. W e b s t e r deserves every e n l o u n i g e m e n t fbl his etlbrts t o d e v e l o p living nnd native
t a l e n t , e n d gratify the public by presenting them with dramas

of t h e a g e , its form a n d pressure. In subservience t o this

mid < eitainly the best a d a p t e d to t h e resources of t h e H a y Maikel T h e a t r e . N o w h e r e else c a n comedy be s o well
represented.
' O l d H e a d s nnd Y o u n g Hearts prepared t h e
p l a y - g o t T for antithesis .-nid repartee in t h e dialogue, a n d
Strong contrasts in the i biiractirs.

T h e pretensions of the comedy a n d its author, in this
instance, seem, t o d e p e n d , in a very great d e g r e e ,
on t h e dialogue, and to this w e a r e disposed willingly t o

superficial, occasionally brilliant.
H e surprises and p l e a s e s
too, by a happy allusion or pointed p h r a s e . T h e a u d i e n c e

of t h e play, nnd this they undoubtedly achieved.
As a
w h o ' e it went oil" well, a n d w a s uproariously a p p l a u d e d a t
the conclusion. T h e piece is admirably p r o d u c e d , and h a *

effect to every scene. W e feel hound t o add that the r e p o r t

in it must ensure t h e development of whatever merit it

p r o d u c e d h e r e , ita reception does n o t admit of d o u b t . I t i s

OPINIONS of t h e PRESS.

" Old H e a d s and Young- H e a r t s , ' ' by Mr. Dioti Bourcicnult,
w a s produced a t this theatre last night with t h e m o s t entire
and unqualified success. It is lull of amusing' i n c i d e n t a n d
lively bustle which never allow t h e interest in t h e d e v e l o p ment of the plan and story of t h e play to flag. T h e dialogue
is r e m a r k a b l . for what is called " smartness ;'' it frequently
rises into the brilliant and sparkling, and no w h e r e limps or
h a n g s fire. Every joku and sarcasm c a m e ns a decided hit,
a n d t h e laughter and applause, which followed t h e m were
both hearty and s p o n t a n e o u s . "Hie c h a r a c t e r s w e r e , m o r e over, all individually well drawn a n d nicely c o n t r a s t e d , and
t h e parts were strongly cast. T h e piece closes with t h e
m a r r i a g e of the lovers in the m o s t approved form, and t h e
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of a p p l a u s e . T h e scenery
and dresses wen, very splendid. N o t h i n g could be in better
t a s t e than L o r d P o m p i o n ' s d r a w i n g - r o o m . T h e piece will
d o u b t l e s s h a r e a long run.—Globe.
T h e comedy is p o t splendidly upon t h e s t a g e , and may be
pronounced perfectly successful.— Belts IVeekly
Messenger.
Every scene produced s o m e t h i n g u n e v p e c t e d , anil very
c l . l "rly contrived.—Court Caxe/te.
T h e Hay market is a t length s e t u p with a new comedy
t h a t is likely t o attract for » time. O l d H e a d s a n d Y o u n g
H e a r t * has hit t h e taste of t h e town.
Smartly written,
cleverly performed, a n d handsomely p u t on t h e s i n g e vivacious e n o u g h to be entertaining— this last production of
M r . Bourcicault was received with acclamations o n t h e first
n i g h t . Tt is written u p to comedy pilch, — The
Spectator.
T h a t l o n g - s o u g h t philosopher'* s t o n e , a five-nct comedy,
h a s a t length been found ; M r . W e b s t e r is t h e fortunate
discoverer. T h e M u s e , that would not b e bribed with t h e
t e m p t i n g p u r s e of i»« hundred golden guineas, lias, of her
o w n free-will, g r a n t e d t h e thing wanted
M r . D i o n Bourcicaillt is t h e favored a g e n t through whom she h a s made this
present to t h e world. ' Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s ' is the
'mine of this dramatic prodigy ; which, t h o u g h haply many
imbued with very critical prejudices may dispute its title to
t h e n a m e , we must in justice pronounce it to h e a legitimate
comedy. T h e r e is within it that sterling stuff of t h e head, if
not Of the heart, which qualifies it to take its station amongst
o u r standard dramas. T h e c h a r a c t e r s a r e developed with
g r e a t skill; t h e l a n g u a g e i s sparkling and vivacious ; t h e
cast of characters having been a s s t r o n g ns it possibly could
b e , and t h e mise-en-scene
b e i n g m o s t admirable, it w a s
entirely and unequivocally successful.
Plaudits, l o n g and
loud and universal, denoted that t h e seal of public approval
had been set upon it. T h e g r e a t e s t praise is undoubtedly duo
to M r . W e b s t e r for his selection of this successful e o m e d y ,
and for t h e liberal manner in w h i c h ho has p r o d u c e d it. It
is likely to have an immense run.—Court Journal.
W e may a t o n e . $ay that t h e success of t h e piece w a s
most complete a n d decided. O l d H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t ,
h a s earned its appellation. M r . Bourcicault's main stay has
b e e n equivoquet ban mots, quaint views of t h e motives and
springs »f fashionable life, and s m a r t r e p a r t e e ; materials of
w Inch he has a great abundance at e o m m a n d , and uses them
very skilfully and pleasantly—sometimes rising even above
t h e refined witticism* of the School for $can<f<ii, and rarely
falling b-'low t h o hroad drolleries of Colmnn's five-act
e x t r a v a g a n z a s . — Atla-i.

GHCZNEE LODGE.

Th.

•

Mr. Bourcicault, whose freshness of spirit delighted t h e
t o w n when he presented his London Assurance, p r o d u c e d a
new comedy here o n M o n d a y , under t h e title of Old Jfrads
and Young Heartt,
a n d it met wit!-, decided success. W e
admit that much of the a p p l a u s e w a s elicited by t h e a c t i n g ,
and scenic a r r a n g e m e n t s ; but t h e play itself possesses t h e
e l e m e n t s of success ; it is lively, witty, a n d amusing—full of
b u s t l i n g incidents a n d dramatic effects. T h e applause given
to t h e n e w comedy w a s hearty a n d u n i v e r s a l . — B e l t s New
VFeekly
Messenger.

OPINIONS of t h e PRESS.
" Old H e a d s and Young H e a r t s , ' ' by Mr. Diot> Bourcicnult,
was produced ot this theatre last night with the most entire
mid unqualified success. I t is full of amusing incident and
lively bustle which never allow the interest in the developm e n t of t h e plnrt and story of the play, to flag. T h e dialogue
is remarkable for what is called " smartness ;*' it frequently
rises into t h . brilliant and sparkling, and Jio w h e r e limps or
h a n g s tire. Every j o k e a n a snrensm came ns a decided hit,
Hiid the In lighter and a p p l a u s e which followed them were
b o t h hearty and spontaneous. T h e character! were, moreover, all individually well drawn and nicely contrasted, and
t h e parts were stronglv cast. T h e piece closes with t h e
marriage of t h e lovers in the most approved form, and the
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of applause. T h e scenery
and dresses were very splendid. Nothing could he in better
t a s t e than Lord Pompiou's drawing-room. T h e piece will
doubtless have a long run.—Globe,
T h e comedy is put splendidly upon the stnyit, and may he
pronounced perfectly successful.-—Bell's Weekly
Messenger,
Every scene produced something unexpected, and very
cleverly contrived.—Court Gazette.
T h e n a y m a r k e t i t a t length set u p with a new comedy
t h a t ia likely to attract for a time. Old H e a d s and Y o n n g
H e a r t * has hit the taste of the town.
Smartly written,
cleverly performed, and handsomely p u t on t h e stage —
v'mieions enough lo be entertaining this Inst production of
Mr. Bourcicault was received with acclamations OS the lirst
n i g h t . It ia written tin to comedy pitch.—The Spectator.
T h a t l o n g - s o u g h t philosopher's stone, a five-act comedy,
h a s at length been found ; Mr, W e b s t e r is t h e fortunate
discoverer. T h e Muse, that would not b e bribed with t h e
t e m p t i n g purse of five hundred golden g u i n e a s , has, of h e r
o w n free-will, granted t h e t h i n g wanted
M r . Dion Bourcicault is the favored agent through whom she has made this
present to the world. ' Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s ' is the
name of this dramatic prodigy ; which, t h o u g h haply manyimbued with very critical prejudices may dispute its title to
t h e name, we must in j u s t i c e pronounce it to lie a legitimate
comedy. T h e r e is within it that sterling stuff of the head, if
not of the h e a r t , which qualifies it to take its Btation amongst
our standard dramas. T h e characters are developed with
g r e a t s k i l l ; t h e l a n g u a g e i s sparkling and vivacious; t h e
cast of characters having been a s strong as it possibly could
be, and t h e mise-en-sr.ene b e i n g most admirable, it waa
entirely and unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long and
loud and universal, denoted that the seal of public approval
had been set upon it. T h e greatest praise is undoubtedly due
t o Mr. W e b s t e r for his selection of fhis successful comedy,
and for t h e liberal manner in which he h a s produced it. It
is likely to have an immense run.— Court
Journal,
W e may a t once any that t h e success of the piece w a s
most complete and decided. Old Heads and Y o u n g Hearts
has earned its appellation. Mr. Boureiemilt ,'i main stay has
been equivoque, bon mots, quaint views of t h e motives and
springs <>! fashionable life, and smart r e p a r t e e : materials of
which he has a great abundance at command, and uses them
•very skilfully and pleasantly—-sometime, rising even above
the refined witticisms of the School for Scandal, and rarely
falling below t h e broad drolleries of Colman's live-act
extra
—Allan.

Mr. Bourcicault, whose freshness of spirit delighted the
town when M presented his London Assvrance, p r o d u c e d a
new comedy h e r e on Monday, u n d e r the title of Old Heads
and Young Hearts, and it met with decided success. W e
admit that much of the applause was elicited b y t h e acting,
and scenic a r r a n g e m e n t * ) but the plav itself possesses the
elements of success ; it. is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. T h e applause given
to the new comedy was hearty and universal.—ttelTs NeV*
Weekly
Messenger.
Old H e a d s and Young Hearts was played for t h e second
time l u t n i g h t , and again received with rapturous applause
by a crowded a u d i e n c e . W e have much pleasure t o affirm
that it is very excellently written, and will add much to the
author's reputation as a dramatist. It evinces a most accurate
k n o w l e d g e of s t a g e effect. T h e comedy is admirably b r o u g h '
out, and the performers exerted themselves t o t h e utmost.
T h e comedy, we a r e certain, will have a long and prosperous
career.—Theatrical Obsei ver.
T h e production of new and original pieces is so laudable
to a managerial a t t e m p t , that Mr. Webster deserves every e n r o u r a g e m . H t for his efforts t o develop living and native
talent, and gratify t h e public by presenting them with dramas
that, b e i n g of the time, reflect the time, and s h o w the body
of the age, its form nnd pressure. I n subservience to this
end, the comic m u s e is, p e r h a p s , t h e most available in itself,
and certainly the best adapted to the resources of t h e H a y Market T h e a t r e . N o w h e r e .else can comedy b e s o well
represented. ' O l d H e a d s and Y o u n g Hearts prepared the
play-goer for antithesis and repartee in t h e dialogue, and
strong contrasts in the characters.
W e were heartily glad,
however, that, the audience recognised the m a n a g e r s good
intentions, and justified the a p p l a u s e with which t h e curtain
eventually fell on the new play.— r/«i
Athenmum.
T h e pretensions of the comedy and its author, in this
instance, seem, t o depend, in a very g r e a t d e g r e e ,
on the dialogue, and to this w e are disposed willingly to
accord no small amount of merit. His dialogue is showy,
superficial, occasionally brilliant.
He surprises and pleases
too, b j . happy allusion or pointed phrase. T h o audience
were kept skiffully in suspense till the very close. T h e
performers exerted themselves zealously to secure the success
of t h e play, and this they undoubtedly achieved.
As a
whole it went off well, and was uproariously a p p l a u d e d at
the conclusion. T h e piece is admirably produced, nnd h a s
every adventitious appliance fitted to aid in giving reality and
effect to every s c e n e . W e feel b o u n d to add that t h e report
we hear of its nightly reception since, warrants t h e belief
that it will have a run that will repay the manager for its production ; while the acting of such performers as are e n g a g e d
in it, must ensure the development of whatever merit, it
possesses.—Satirist.
W h a t e v e r name is g i v e n ' t o t h e entertainment in live acts
produced h e r e , its reception does not admit of d o u b t . It is
greatly successful. W e did not see it until T h u r s d a y , when,
in despite and defiance of the fog, we found the enjoyment
of a large audience clear and indisputable. L a u g h t e r was
hearty and unrestrained, and t h e curtain fell to peals of prolonged ajoplause. T h e a r r a n g e m e n t s of the s e e n , are all in
the b d h possible taste,
-Examiner.

" Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s , ' ' by Mr. Dion
flourcicnult,
was produced a t this theatre last n i g h t with t h e most entire
and unqualified success. I t is full of a m u s i n g incident a n d
lively hustle which never allow the interest in t h e d e v e l o p ment of the plan and story of the piny to f\ng. T h e dialogue
is remarkable for what is called " s m a r t n e s s ;" it frequently
rises into the brilliant nnd sparkling, and n o where limps or
h a n g s fire. E v e n j o k e and sarcasm ciime as a decided hit,
and t h . laughter and npplause which followed them were
both hearty and spontaneous. T h e characters were, m o r e over, all individually viell drawn and nicely contrasted, and
the parts were strongly CRst. T h e piece closes with t h e
marriage of t h e lovers in the most approved form, and t h e
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of applause. The H anerj
and dresses were very splendid. N o t h i n g could be in better
t«>te than Lord Pompion's drnwing-room. T h e piece will
doubtless have a long run.—Globe.

T h e comedy is p u t splendidly upon t h e Mafic, and may b e
pronounced perfect!* successful.—Bell's Wetklp
Maienger.

cleverly contrived.— Cowl
Gazette.
T h e H a y m a r k e t is nt length set u p «i<h a new comedy
that is likely to attract for a time. Old Heads and Y o u n g
H e a r t s h a s hit the taste of the town.
Smartly Writt.lt,
eleverly performed, and handsomely p u t on t h e stage nvnoious enough to be entertaining— this lust production of
Mr. Boureicault was received with acclamations on t h e first
night. I t is written u p to comedy pitch.—The Spectator.
T h a t long-sought philosopher's stone, a five-net comedy,
h a s a t length been found ; M r . W e b s t e r is t h e fortunate
discoverer. T h e Muse, that would n o t b e bribed with t h e
tempting purse of five hundred golden guineas, has, of h e r
o w n free-will, granted t h e thing wanted
M r . Dion B o u t c i cault i» t h e favored agent through whom s h e h a s made this
present to the world. ' Old Heads and Y o u n g H e a r t s ' is t h e
name of this dramatic prodigy ; which, t h o u g h haply many
imbued with very critical prejudices may dispute its title to
the n a m e , we must in iustice pronounce it to M a legitimate
comedy. T h e r e is within it that sterling stuff of t h e head, if
not of the h e a r t , which qualifies it to take its station amongst
our standard dramas. T h e characters a r e developed with
g r e a t s k i l l ; t h e l a n g u a g e is sparkling a n d vivacious; t h e
oast of characters having been as s t r o n g as it possibly could
be, a n d t h e mutftn-scene
b e i n g most admirable, it w a s
entirely and unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long and
loud and universal, denoted that the seal of public approval
had been set upon it. T h e greatest praise i* undoubtedly due
t o Mr. W e b s t e r for his selection of this successful comedy,
and for the liberal manner in which h e h a s produced it. I t
is likely to have an i m m e n s e run.—Court Journal.

W e may a t once - a y that t h e success of the piece w a s
most complete and decided. Old H e a d s and Y o u n g H e a r t s
h a s earned its appellation. Mr. Bourcicault's main stay haa
b e e n equivoque, lion mots, quaint views of t h e motives a n d
•prings o f fashionable life, and smart r e p a r t e e ; materials of
which he has a great abundance at c o m m a n d , and uses them
very skilfully and pleasantly—sometimes rising even above
t h e refined witticisms of t h e School for Scandal, and rarelyfalling below t h e broad drolleries of Column's five-act
extravagan*as.-~Jtf«w.

Mr. Pi urcicault, whose freshness of spirit delighted t h e
town « h e n h e presented his London Atiurance, produced a
new comedy here on Monday, under the title of Old Head*
and Young tftart$,
and it met with decided success. W e
admit that much of the applause was elicited by the acting,,
and scenic o r r a n g e m e n t s ; but t h e play itself possesses t h e
elements of success : it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. T h e applause g i v e n
to (he i i ' w comedy was hearty and universal.—Bell's New
Weekly
Messenger.
Old H e a d s and Young H e a r t s w a s played for the sei e n d
time last nipht, and again received with rapturous n p p l a u s .
by n crowded audience. W e have much pleasure to affirm
that it is very excellently viriticn, and will a d d much to t h e
author's reputation as a dramatist. It evinces a most a c c u r a t e
knowledge of stage effect. 1 he comedy is admirably brough*
out, mid the performers excited themselves to the u t m o s t .
' I h e comedy, « e are certain, will have a long and prosperous)
career.— Theatrical
Observer.
T h " production of new a n d original pieces is so laudable
to a mnnairerial attempt, that Mr.; W e b s t e r deserves every e n couragement for his efforts". to-"'develop living and native
talent, and gratify the public by presenting them with d r a m a s
that, b e i n g of t h e time, reflect t h e time, and show the b o d y
of t h e age its form nnd p r e s s u r e . I n subservience to this
end, the comic muse is, perjiaps, t h e most available in itself,
and certainly the best a d a p t e d to the resources of the H a y Market T h e a t r e . N o w h e r e else can cotrtedy b e s o w e l l
reptesented. ' O l d Heads and Young H e a r t s prepared t h e
play-goer for antithesis and repartee in t h e dialogue, a n d
strong contrasts in the characters.
W e were heartily g l a d ,
however, that t h e audience recognized t h e m a n a g e r s g o o d
intentions, and justified the a p p l a u s e with which t h e curtain
eventually fell ofi the new play.--77«t
Athewtum.
T h e pretensions of the comedy a n d its author, in this
instance, seem, t o d e p e n d , in * a very g r e a t d e g r e e ,
on the dialogue, and to this w e a r e disposed willingly t »
accord no small amount of merit. H i s dialogue is s h o w y ,
superficial, occasionally brilliant.
H e surprises and p l e a s e ,
too, by a happy allusion or pointed p h r a s e . T h e audience
were kept skilfully in suspense till t h e very close. T h .
performers exerted themselves zealously t o secure the success,
of the play, and this they undoubtedly achieved.
As •
whole it went off well, a n d w a s uproariously applauded a t
the conclusion. T h e piece is admirably produced, and h a s
every adventitious appliance fitted to aid in giving reality a n d
effect to every scene. W e feel b o u n d to add that the r e p o r t
we hear of its nightly reception since, warrants t h e belief
that it will have a run that will repay the m a n a g e r for its p r o duction ; while the acting of such performers a s are e n g a g e d
in it must ensure t h e development o f whatever merit i t
possesses.—Satirist.
